Basic frame / standoff for the Adafruit Huzzah ESP8266 Breakout board (https://www.adafruit.com/product/2471). Just enough to get it off the workbench, but not impede access to the pins.

Muzzle cap for your AR15. It should fit most A2/M4 style flash hiders. It's tight enough that it should keep any water or crud out without falling off. I don't know that it would be "shoot through", but why would you want to, especially if you put your custom logo?!

I've included 2 different models - the first is just a plain cap, and the 2nd has the Punisher logo. You can use Tinkercad and import any logo you want by converting a clip art picture in Selva3d, and then place it on the top of the plain version. Be sure that the logo and the top of the cap are interwoven in Tinkercad, otherwise they are likely to separate when you go to print.

You can print the plain model with the top of the cap on the printer bed with no supports. If you print one with a logo, have it with the logo side at the top and use supports. No raft or brim are needed, even if you print 2 colors. Or just print it one color, and paint the logo as you desire.

Update 9/17/2017: First print started to split after repeated installation/removal, so I recommend scaling to 101% when you print.

remixed_from.title: Master Sword (Full Size) - Legend of Zelda

description.text:
Inspired from Breath of the Wild and the Adafruit guardian sword build. Seemed like a logical next step to combine the two and since ChaosCoreTech had already released a fantastic model to start with I opted to use that as my base to remix.

Designed to be printed on a CR-10 S5 so the pieces are in the 450-525mm length. Obviously that's not going to fly for the average printer but I wanted to test my build volume since it's a 500mm cube! Another major reason for making the parts so big was to reduce the visible seams when light passes through. Aside from welding material into the cracks then sanding I don't know a better way to handle seams beyond molding and casting.
Eventually I will make an effort to modify the parts to work on smaller build plates, but I don't know how soon..

Materials Needed;

Natural PLA - http://amzn.to/2CzulxY
Adafruit NeoPixels - http://amzn.to/2kvyTgu
Trinker Pro 5V Logic - http://amzn.to/2Bc0Vpd
Battery Charge board - http://amzn.to/2AQF1uZ
Hook-Up Wire - http://amzn.to/2jXxgca
Soldering Iron Starter Kit - http://amzn.to/2jXydkK
3D Printer CR-10 S5 - http://amzn.to/2zeE7pv
Acrylic Paints - http://amzn.to/2Cyr16i

Printer:

Creality CR-10 S5

Resolution:

200 Microns

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Okay for this build I'd advise printing it in PLA on a heated glass bed with a layer of glue stick applied for adhesion. Glass makes a beautiful mirror finish that pops off easily and gives you a really flat surface.

You'll need;
Adafruit hardware (see guardian sword build for parts list)
PLA/ABS natural white (not clear- it's too clear)
Large format printer

Steps
1) Print 3D Parts
2) Assemble Lighting Circuit
3) Program Circuit with Arduino
4) Clean 3D Parts
5) Mount Electronics
6) Bond Sword Halves
7) Paint & Seal
8) Vanquish Evil
Remixed in Tinkercad, just a few grouping off parts then a symmetry cut and a few internal cut outs nothing too fancy.

author: xaloes

description.text:
These are clips that can be printed and attached to plywood that can be used to help secure it in the frame if a window. There are products out there that are sturdier, made of metal and stronger, but they were all out. If anything those products on a strength rating are a 10 out of 10 and PLA strength rating is a 2 out of 10... 3 at most. But if you print a lot of them they will get the job done.

Now these you do not shove them back into the frame as you would their metal counterparts. you place them on the edges of the plywood, you can secure them down with screws or not.... you can edit them down so it is closer to the thickness of the plywood you do have. But after they are arrayed on your plywood you take the pronged end of the clips and bend it so that they grip into the sides of your window frame. Ye you do need to print a lot of them for a small or medium window, but it can help you protect your house during the oncoming storm.

Printing on a Dremel Idea Machine 3D printer to print the Hurricane Clip set and Board Coupler set on one bed under 3 hours. a single clip under 40 minutes. This does mean it will take some time to print enough to cover an average house worth of windows, but it is a help cover what you can in a night of printing.

description.text:
OpenDungeonTiles: Floor Flagstone Opening 2x2

Assembly:
Walls take 5mm magnetic spheres
Floors take 3mm magnetic spheres
Bases take 5mm magnetic spheres
Insert 5mm magnetic spheres into the 2 holes, glue thinner piece on top. When placing other parts onto the base, the thinner glued on part should be on the bottom. (I am working on assembly video/instructions)

Open Forge Compatible.
Open Lock Compatible (Note: You must use the lock in my files it is thinner)

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

Questions - use the comments, send me a message here or on patreon.

title: Flexion HT + FlashForge/PowerSpec/CTC Extruder Fan Spacer

description.text:
The cooling block that comes with the (excellent/amazing/life-changing) Flexion HT extruder has heatsink fins that press up against the connector segment of the original (excellent/amazing/life-changing) one-piece spacer replacement from CBiker. This slight modification moves the connector segment up so that it runs above those fins but below the gear shaft. It should press right against the cage of the fan and dampen the vibration sound very well.

I printed in beautiful green PETG, but ABS or other heat-tolerant stuff should be good.

This is a one piece display stand for a ribbon drape medal.The pin portion simply fits over the hook at the end. It was designed to be incredibly stable for heavy medals, and strong enough to not flex. It was also designed so that supports are not needed for printing which saves a lot of material, but a smaller layer height will help the printer deal with the overhangs so the print turns out well. This is a reed for the Duck Call by jamesarm97 https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38359
I've got my mind focused on a playable reed and after few trials this is it.
There are two files reed 3 and reed 4mm. The first is 0.3mm reed and produces loud deeper sound. The 0.4mm is more authentic and more tunable.

PLA print in 0.100, all solid layers and outline shell of 1

The reed will be printed bigger about 1.5 mm on each side than needed, because you are going to cut out the part where the nozzle turns and creates rough and thicker spots. So cut out the rough edges from left, right and top.

See the first image and the microscope image, the top is cut reed, the bottom is straight from the printer.

With this reed the duck call is fully functional and as good as store bought.
When you are removing it from bed, wait till it cools down so it will not bend or curl. Use razor blade. When removed, you want it flat.
You can scrape or sand the top just little to smooth it if it is too rough.

Sound depends how you position the reed with the wedge. There is a thicker lip of the reed that goes under the wedge. The sound is more clean when that lip is all under the wedge and more raspy when that lip peeks from the top. With the 0.4mm you can tune it to any sound. You can also scrape the top with the razor blade to shave a few micrometers.
If you use glass as bed the bottom will be mirror smooth.

It is interesting that you can now easily produce good reed with 3d printing in PLA with today machines. I am going to make a sax reed next to see how it compares.

Good luck talking to ducks. Don't use while driving.

title: Simple Fan Holder for the Flex Wheel extruder

description.text:
This is a simple fan holder for the Flex Wheel Extruder, it can used with both the direct drive and bowden cable set ups.

It helps stop the heat travelling from the motor through the gearbox into the extruder mechanism.

Chose where you would like to mount the fan on the extruder and print appropriate file.

Additional hardware required.

To attach fan to bracket - 2 x M3 x 20 mm
To attach bracket to the Flex Wheel extruder - 1 x M3 x 35 mm & 1 x M3 x 20 mm.

description.header: More about the Flex Wheel Extruder
description.text:
The flex wheel is a revolutionary new type of extruder mechanism which has completely moved away form the problematic hobbed gear pinch type roller system.

No more clogged hobbed gear, no more under extrusion problems, no more kinking of flexible filament, just more contact surface area transferring more power which drives your filament harder and faster, the Flex Wheel, designed for flex but prints everything the best.

www.flexwheelextruder.com

title: Arcade Machine with Pi 3 Panel Remix

description.text:
I'm going to build one of these arcades, but did not like the layout, so I've recreated the panel in openSCAD to make it easier to rearrange the layout.

Have not printed yet.

I'm using the Japanese layout from http://slagcoin.com/joystick/layout.html

  • panel.stl is the default panel.
  • panel_japan.stl repositions the stick and buttons off-center to fit everything at the right spacing
  • panel_japan_small.stl attempts to keep the stick and buttons center, messing up the spacing between the buttons and joysticks.

I could make more layouts if there are any requests.

title: Inverted Tooth Brush Stands
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
'Inverted' Toothbrush Stands provide a practical, common sense alternative way to store your Toothbrush. The files provided (for 1 / 2 / 3 / 4 toothbrushes) should work with most types of Toothbrush. They are small. quick and easy prints that can be printed in everyone's personal favourite colors.

The common way to store Toothbrushes is in a jar or holder that is exposed to both airborne dirt / dust in the area plus water splashed from the nearby basin. In addition, Toothbrushes stored with the head facing upwards allow any excess water (with contaminants) to run down the handle after brushing. Not that these are big issues for most people but the Inverted Toothbrush Stands addresses all of these issues.... refer to the images for additional explanation.

Inverted Toothbrush Stands are easy to use. Just lean the head of your Toothbrush backwards, insert on angle and keep the bristles clear of the top edge, rotate the handle around and into the top slot until the back of the Toothbrush heads is at the back of the stand. The Toothbrush should stand and self centre. The bristles will be clear of the floor in the stand and still exposed to air due to the side vents... but any splashed water will not reach the bristles. Refer to the images for additional information.

Files have been provided to accommodate 1 / 2 / 3 / 4 Toothbrushes. They are all small and easy prints with no support required. A simple way to organize your Toothbrushes and overcome everyday issues.

Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information... and post images of your Inverted Toothbrush Stands in use for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 20% infill recommended

Notes:

Easy prints. Do not use automated support required. No support required.

Just add your Toothbrush...

Refer to the images for instruction on correct use. There is a simple process for inserting and removing brushes. Easy once you know how...

I've had my first printer for 3 days as of this post.

I was very unhappy with the original extruder setup on the Anet A8. Every time the filament gets stuck or breaks inside the extruder you have to disassemble the whole part. This is especially annoying because the screws for the fan also attach the heatsinkt and the stepper motor to the lower block to which the hotend is screwed in.

Anyway, i found a few fan mounts here on thingiverse but decided to make on myself. This is the result. Please keep in mind that this is also a crutch solution to an inherent problem the whole kit has. I am only intending to use it until i upgrade the whole hotend to a better one with a more user friendly extruder.

description.text:
I did not find a nice Roomba wall mount that had all the features that I wanted. To further hone my skills with Fusion 360, I made it fully parametrized and fancy! To this end you can download the f3d file and set the following user parameters (check the "Change Parameters"):

  • wallToBase: the length between the lower lip of the base station and the wall, this way you can bridge a gap or a baseboard.
  • baseboardHeight: the height of the baseboard or zero if you do not have this
  • screwDiameter: the diameter of the screw thread
  • screwHeadDiameter: the diameter of the screw head
  • slant: the slant of your wall (my walls are not straight) and add 1.5 deg slant of the base station itself.

If you do not have Fusion 360 or you just quickly want a STL file with the correct parameters, ask in the comments and I will quickly generate one for you!

description.text:
Finally I can quickly set my camera position correctly whether sittin or standing when playing PSVR :)

title: 2pc box in assortment box box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I bought an wall mounting assortment box with several boxes in there. Each of this boxes can be seperated by a small plastic "seperator-card". You can seperate each box up to 3 times. And you got 5 of this "seperator-cards" in packaging. - Did I mention, that you can buy 10pc of this cards for about 3€!? There is no way for me to buy them, cause there are 36 boxes in it.

Because i'm soldering out electrical parts to reuse them, I need a solution to get them sorted. First I "designed" one of these seperator-cards, but then I took the decision, that placing boxes in the box is much more useful. - So I can easily take one single box out, I can resort them quickly and I can place a sticker on it. <- That's useful, because i'm going to use barcodes and a software to get an index.

I got many parts in small amounts, so I decided to build boxes, which fit 2, 3 and 4 times in the original box. I build a "6 time box" as well, but you can't handle it usefully, without empty the whole box or using tweezers.

The original assortment box I bought at „Hornbach“. It’s a german hobbymarket / building suppy store / hardware store. The assortment box got no brand name. It’s just labeled with „Made in Germany“.

I designed a „4 times box“ and a „3 times box“ as well.

4pc box in box
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2525804

3px box in box
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2525843

Ich habe mir einen Sortimentskasten mit zahlreichen Schubladen für eine Wandmontage gekauft. Jede dieser Schubladen kann mit einer „Trennkarte“ unterteilt werden. Bis zu drei Unterteilungen pro Box sind möglich. Fünf „Trenner“ sind im Lieferumfang enthalten. Sie lassen sich in 10er-Paketen nachbestellen für etwa 3€ pro Stück. Das ist für mich nicht tragbar, da das Sortiment 36 Schubladen umfasst, von der jede theoretisch dreifach unterteilt werden kann.

Da ich elektronische Bauteile für Wiederverwendung aus alten Geräten auslöte und aufbewahre, möchte ich sie vernünftig sortiert wissen. Zunächst designte ich einen dieser „Trenner“, musste aber feststellen, dass das kein für mich gangbarer Weg ist. Ich erstellte also Boxen, die in die Schublade des Sortiments passten. So kann ich eine Box einfach entnehmen und alle auch einzeln beschriften. <- Das ist in meinem Fall sinnvoll, da ich die Boxen noch mit Barcodes beschriften und einer Software katalogisieren werde.

Durch das Auslöten habe ich viele Teile in kleinen Mengen und ich entschied mich deswegen, zwei, drei oder vier kleine Boxen in eine Schublade zu packen. Ein kleineres Design ist kaum mehr sinnvoll, da man es schlecht entnehmen kann und die Teile entweder auskippen oder mit einer Pinzette entnehmen muss. Man kommt schlichtweg mit den Fingern nicht mehr in die Box. Zu klein. – Ein Design mit vier Boxen ist möglich. Dazu mehr weiter unten.

Den Sortimentskasten habe ich für wenige Euros bei Hornbach gekauft. Der Kasten selber hat keine Angabe eines Herstellers, sondern trägt lediglich das Prädikat: „Made in Germany“.

Ich habe diverse Box-Sets designt: Neben dieser „2er-Box“ gibt es noch eine „4er-Box“ und eine „3er-Box“. Dies ist das Design für die 3er-Box.

4er Box in Box:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2525804

3er Box in Box:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2525843

Printer:

Freesculpt EX1

Rafts:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Shell: 0,4, Top/Bottom 1,0
printed in yellow PET-G from Minadax @ 215°C nozzle & 80°C bed

I printed 3 of these boxes at one time. Maybe you can do more once.

Maybe you have to turn the modell in your sclicer! I'm using Cura and I had to turn it about 180° in direction, because Cura ment the bottom is the top side!
You don't have to invest much work in it. I had to cleanup the bottom, because of the marks of the buildplate. Otherwise I only cleaned up the angelhair.

I designed this model in FreeCAD.

It's a simple rectangle as a box. And there is another smaller rectangle as a pocket. That's all.

There is a lot of dust collecting in hard-to-reach places around the house, for example, behind the radiators. This is probably a concern in many households. Our vacuum cleaner Henry didn’t have a suitable nozzle to get through narrow spaces. Therefore, we designed a customised nozzle in TinkerCAD. It consists of several parts and is easy to print.

First part "Main" goes on the original vacuum cleaner hose.
Extension 1 can be made longer in a slicer to fit your printer's build plate.
Extension 2 adds length to extension 1 if needed.

title: Honda S2000 Throttle Pedal Heel-&-Toe Accessory

description.text:
WORK IN PROGRESS.
This is a 3D printed throttle pedal extension accessory designed to help with 'heel & toe' braking with engine rev matching during down gear shifts in a Honda S2000. Where some drivers (like me with big feet) have difficulty with the standard throttle pedal position and spacing.
Aftermarket and DIY pedals are available made in sheet metals, but I think this 3D printable plastic extension may well be a first (if not then send me the WWW link). The 3D printed pedal extension accessory requires no modifications to the OEM pedal, it can be customised, it can be easily removed if required.

The design evolved in two parts, a Grip, and a Tab. The Grip slides onto a OEM Honda pedal from below, the Tab attaches to the Grip and provides the new pedal surface. Originally I was going to make the whole thing in one piece, but it makes more sense now to keep the design as two parts so the Tab can be easily customised by me or by others to suit their own needs (ankle reach and foot width etc).

The Grip is a snug fit to the OEM pedal and can be lightly glued with RTV on the sides and/or on the back, the Tab on this prototype design is meant to be glued to the Grip before installation, using epoxy or CA glues. For test fitting it will just snap together via locating bumps on both pieces if printed correctly.

I printed prototypes in ABS at 0.2mm layers on a well tuned Prusa i3, if your printer is good then the parts should be a snug fit. If not then rescale very slightly on the slicer software (on both parts). The Grip is best printed upright with the lower surface on the print bed (as seen on the fitted photos), the Grip is best print flat, with the back surface down.

STL files are at correct scale to be printed, but the SKP (Sketchup) files are at 1000x (m = mm) because Sketchup Make has issues with parts with small sharp corners.
The project is ongoing, I am still settling down the width and height (above OEM pedal surface) of the Tab and expect to have a V3 or V4 in a couple of months time.

If you try one and create a new Tab please report it on Thingiverse.
Good luck and happy rev matching :)

title: Snake lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This lamp is inspired by the snake puzzle game. with the right power source (3[V] x[A]) you can make it as long as you want.
the lamp can be oriented in any way and will stay constantly on.
The "conductive ring" pieces must be made out of metal or highly conductive filament (in the prototype they are PLA coated with tinfoil).
Each cube contains 4 leds, all mounted in parallel. the positive pole will touch the inner ring while the negative, the inner one. In the cube there are tunnels where the wires pass through to connect the rings on the two sides.
the electrical socket is of the type present on Arduino (the one used for 12V] usually).
the lamp is held together by an elastic cord.
the locking system is identical to that of the previously loaded snake puzzle cube

title: Automatic part unloader for Ultimaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are parts for an automatic part unloader I made for the Ultimaker 2. With some adaptions it can be used with many other 3d printers. The parts were printed with PLA at a layer height of 0.25 mm

video at https://youtu.be/xMVE7-IOp78

Beside the 3d printed parts you will need:
aluminium strip 10 X 2 X 304 mm
aluminium strip 10 X 2 X 317 mm
aluminium L shaped profile 10 X 10 X 1 X 200 mm
steel strip 30 X 2 X 169 mm
M3 rod 188mm
aprox 1700 mm of strong thread (ie dynama 13kg)
5 brass pulleys 6 X1.7 mm
knife 81 mm (wall paper scraper knife)
about 10 M2 screws
about 8 m2 nuts
4 m3 screws
some iron wire 1.2 mm
servo (ie hobbyking 9225000012)
microswitches and electronic parts

The unloading is started by pressing a micro switch . This micro switch is operated by sending the extruder to a corner. With special software you can merge multiple gcode files into one file. In this new file the start switch is operated after each model is printed.

So as long the GBB measurement is the same, this should work with a wide range of different 1911 brands. Most important part is the lower tactical rail on the 1911, where the whole setup is fixed on.
Time´s Blog: http://imgur.com/a/niNOt

After printing the original files untouched I started to work on it, optimizing the design. Of course taking it apart to make it easier to print. Adding screw and nut inlets so it's all clean and flush with the body surface. Giving the whole design a more rounded appearance by
Reinforcing the Main Body in the middle part and on the mock shell eject window.
taking off sharp corners and lines.
Added some stylish " racing stripes" ;)
created a charging handle+ skeletonized charging case
created side, top and lower Picatinny rails.
lengthened the buffertube inlet for a more stable mount.
Added my Logo and also the name of the conversion kit.
Added fast detach sling swivel mount option.
Reinforced the Modell at some points where I had "see throughs" after printing the original kit unmodified.
Created a Mock suppressor
Created a Pistol mount fixation ( prevents pistol being kicked out from mounting through blowback action)
Created additional Pistol Grip Guard ( AUG Style) for picatinny Rail.

15x M4x30mm screws + nuts
10x M4x15mm screws+ nuts
1x special length ( you have to figure out yourself) m4 screw for fixing the gun in the carbine conversion kit
( Yes those are more than you actually need, but you know screws drop easily and get lost a lot ;)

!!!!ATTENTION!!!!!! After a while and several Magazines I encountered a problem in the design. I am using a real hard kicking KJW KP-07 CO2 Pistol who kicks the gun backwards and out of the mount!!

the only working way to fix this is to drill a hole on the bottom side of the tactical rail and cut a thread. A Screw is then put through the lower frame and the pistol frame, holding the gun in position!!! A picture was added so you can see what you have to do, also VERY IMPORTANT DONT USE A TOO LONG screw!!!

Otherwise you will block the Slide from cycling!! If you dont pay attention you will BREAK YOUR GUN!!
Screw the bolt it more often and SHORTEN it with a file when needed!!

I am not responsible if you break your gun just because you didn't read the instruction carefully!!!

If you dont have a fitting buttstock check out this really nice design from user Pisu which I also added on the 3D renders. Looks pretty damn well! Dont forget to give him a like when you use it ;)

9/10---- This is just a 3 prong mount, i got tired of making them everytime and no one had them that i could find. so you can build whatever and when you want to add the mount just input it and add done. much faster and easier.

This is fun, it works so good and easy I want to share.
Whatch the videos:
https://youtu.be/1ZVUmNwovrY
https://youtu.be/8I7uNFzRI80
it is real time.

How to:
-Fix a ball-pen on your print-head
-Download Inkscape
-Download and install J-Tech Photonics Inkscape Laser Plug-In:
https://jtechphotonics.com/?page_id=2012
-Set Inkscape document dimensions to printbed size
-Draw or place some paths (set view mode to outline to see what will be drawn)
-Generate gcode using the plugin
for "Laser ON Command" paste into the plugin window:
G91
G1 Z-1.0
G90
for "Laser OFF Command" paste:
G91
G1 Z+1.0
G90

this will move Z up and down 1 mm relative to actual position.
I edit g-code manual just to remove first z + command because I want to start over the paper in off position, and I remove last X0 Y0 because I start with manual moved axis without reference and don´t want it to crash full speed in the end-stops at the end.

-Placing:
in Inkscape measure coordinates of the element you want to place
move printer x y to this coordinates
place paper under pen or move axis manual(by hand steppers off) over paper where it should be drawn

I use Repetier-Host for this, you can move the axis, send custom g-code commands like M18 to turn axis off, and drag the laser g-code and print it direct so you don´t need swapping SD-Card.

Tuning:
I tuned up printer settings speed since we don´t have to wait for the filament to be placed this could go very fast.

So if you are bored making or run out of filament or waiting for your laser head just try to strap a pen on your printer.
My first printer CTC i3 Pro B Mainboard is broken so the extruder stepper does not work, now it is back alive.

author: MrJoce

description.text:
Years ago I made a media basket for my Aquaclear 50 filter based of some designs I saw online with acrylic glass a couple drill bits and silicone. A few years have passed and the silicone is starting to fall apart so I decided to design and 3d print a new one.
The original basket only allowed for two types of media. With this design you can have three (I use carbon, biomax and foam)

Dimensions:

V1
Frame:

  • 128mm (H).
  • 122mm (W).
  • 60mm (D).

Tray:

  • 3mm (H).
  • 72mm (W).
  • 56mm (D).

V2
Frame:

  • 128mm (H).
  • 122mm (W).
  • 55mm/46mm (D) at top/bottom.

Tray:

  • 3mm (H).
  • 72mm (W).
  • 47mm (D).

Update (11-09-2017):
Added V2. Originally I designed the basket based on the measurements of a replacement basket I found online because I didn't want to disable the filter. When I was test fitting I noticed it was to tight so I made some changes in the depth. V2 is 55mm deep at the top and 46mm deep at the bottom. The tray was also changed to 47mm deep. I'm leaving the V1 files online because I don't know if there's any difference in size between American vs European versions or really old (like mine) vs newer ones.

Cubes to get rid off stringing/oozing.

  1. Set up travel speed (for non-printed lines) pretty much high. In my case: 150 mm/s.

  2. Optional: Set retraction settings all off to see how much stringing you will get.

  3. Turn on retraction settings in your slicer.

    • Retraction distance: 1 mm
    • Retraction speed: 50 mm/s

  4. Still some stringing?

    • Increase retraction distance by 1 mm per print and look and your results.
    • I recommend maximum distances up to 5 mm/s for direct driven extruders.

  5. Still stringing?

    • Keep the best setting for your retraction length
    • Start off with a retraction speed of 10 or 20 mm/s and increase by 10 mm/s
    • In recommend maximum retraction speeds of 70 mm/s
  6. You should now see no more stringing. If you stell get stringing, take a look at the following troubleshootings:

a) Overextrusion:
You extrude too much material so that your nozzle runs through printed areas and carries the plastic towards the edges. Try reducing the flow.

b) Machanical problem with Z-Axis:
Your printer does not print the exact height you want it to print and therefore runs through printed layers (see Overextrusion). Take a look at your belt tension or trapezoidal spindle.

c) Printing temperature too high:
Retraction still can't handle very fluid materials, so try to reduce your printing temperature and therefore get a little bit more viscosity to the material.

d) Try to get help in the comments ;-)

Let me know whether you printed the part and it helped you to get rid of stringing/oozing in the comments!

The Kerf of a laser is the width of the blade (laser beam) this varies between machines it changes depending on focus so it could be different for different material thicknesses. Note :- added Feb 2015
The Kerf of the laser is reduced by reducing the power of the laser beam I recently changed my focal lens orientation to be correct thanks to Spooky at the OPL laser forum. For some reason Chinese Laser cutters come with the focal lens upside down.. After researching this I found many drawings from UK and USA laser lens manufactures showing that the convex side of the lens should face down not up . I know it looks logical how it is supplied with the convex side facing up. But the improvement in cutting is noticeable.and i my case the Laser Kerf has gone from 0.2mm down to 0.17 mm.
It is with this tool that you can measure the kerf, of your laser beam. The blocks are 8mm x 10mm this ensures you measure them the right way. It might be worth also marking the top with a pen before removing them from the laser bed the you can put them into the measure in a 1 up 1 down sequence this will eliminate any sloping beam problems from the measurement. It could also be used to measure the slope of the beam with a little more maths.
the how to use Instructions are on the tool

description.text:
Hello , this thing is a simple example of how convert a file image to lithophane (yet anothet lithophane , i think )...
This print was made with white PLA at 0.2 mm. of resolution.
The image to litho conversion was made at low resolution.
Well , if we have the file image , then go to : http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/
upload your file image and adjust some simple and intuitive parameters , choose the final form and we got a .stl file , put on your favorite slicer and you are ready to print the lithophane of your photo.
Sky is the limit ...!! , Xmas lithos for glass windows , leds lamp lithos , Hallowen candle lithos , birthday lithos and so on...
Enjoy ...

UPDATED 14/9/17

Added VFatima3.stl , litho what printed vertically increase the performance of light contrast , made with 5 vectors/pixels (optimal i think...) , thickness of 4,8 mm.
For optimal results your slicer must be adjusted to 6 perimeter shells and add 5 skirt outlines.
For print vertically you must rotate -90º at Y and center and arrange in your slicer...the size of the stl file is huge and can't load ok in Thinkercad ( must be decrease resolution ).
Upgrade font : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KRdMwuBQQ0U

description.text:
If you want to use the latest Marlin Firmware awesome UBL feature along with a BLTouch, you might struggle with some parts of you bed not being probed, due to an xy offset of you probe. This means you need to manually probe the bed with the nozzle. That's time consuming and boring.

That's why I'm designing a zero xy offset BLTouch mount.

After several attempts i found out that the print should be sliced sideways, and not with the flat part down for better strength. The opposite will make your printed part fail between the layers.

Added a clipping support for the probe (when out of use) on top of the effector.

Hi , this is a simple holder for a Joule thief circuit and an AA battery.

If you don't know what a Joule thief is ,search for bigclivedotcom on youtube. It's where I copied the circuit from. There are many other videos that explain it as well though.

Here's the Wiki definition

A joule thief is a minimalist Armstrong self-oscillating voltage booster that is small, low-cost, and easy to build, typically used for driving small loads.

It allows you to run a 3v LED from a single dying 1.5v AA cell. The one in the photo has been running for 37 hours on a dead battery out of a kitchen clock. (starting voltage 0.79v)

The holder is printed at 0.3 with 0 to 20% infill

title: Ikea Kvartal Curtain Track Clip for LED Strips

description.text:
I wanted to put a LED Strip on my Ikea Kvartal curtain track system and found a great solution for standard 12mm selfadhesive LED strips.

Since the track is only 20mm away from the ceiling, putting the LEDs on top was not an option, you would have seen spots from each LED. Therefore I came up with this easy clip-on system. It is sligthly angled toward the ceiling by about 5°.

All you need is a flat strip of 15x2mm aluminium in the matching length ( I used 3x 2m for my living room wall and got it from a hardware store/home depot/DIY market), and a few of these clips (I suggest using one clip every 50-80cm).

Just print them, test the fit with your aluminium strip, then push them in the top of your Kvartal track, it should snap securely in place and still be movable along the track. Then snap the aluminium strip into the holder, by placing it in the top of the clip and pushing down, gently, but firmly. For rounded corners, you should pre-bend the strip and use more clips, if necessary.
Apply your 12mm LED Strip before, or if you use several seperate aluminium strips, after you installed the aluminium strip on the track. The adhesive film should isolate the LED strip and the aluminium will help with cooling the strip. However, you should check the strip for short circuits before plugging it in.

The clips and LEDs are almost invisible until you stand below the curtain. As far as i know, Ikea discontinued the Kvartal curtain track, but it can be found on eBay from time to time, or maybe you already own one.

i hold no responsibility on damage taken on your things if the honeycomb break ALWAYS TEST IT and remember ALWAYS USE EYE PROTECTION! (and reprint another one with the same settings and filament if needed) BEFORE PLAYING WITH IT ON
recomended test settings: , 4-5cm from your ASG, hold it in place with something and shoot the bb at it (only the honeycomb protector alone, don't put your optic through pointless danger)
the resistance of the honeycomb pattern depend on the type of filament and setting you use so try experimenting!

title: BETA - Piezo z-probe for E3D Titan Aero (mounted direct via motor)

description.text:
Precision Piezo presents - Titan Aero (or other similar extruder system) Piezo sensor plate.

This is a beta, I have one working but I am keen to hear your feedback and see any modification you make. Please share.

If you mount your titan aero (or other similar extruder design) direct via the motor screws, then this plate allows you to use piezo z-probing.

Print it in PLA, or PETG (ABS will warp as its tall and thin). Drill out the four holes which match a nema 17 motor pattern to 3.2mm.

Mount between the motor and x-carriage/print head.

Insert a 20mm piezo disc into the top, there is a groove for the solder pads (presuming the use of murata 7bb series 20mm piezo - which are a reliable, known quantity).

Tighten the screws holding the motor, enough to ensure the motor and attached hotend is firm, but not super tight or there won't be a little compliance to allow the piezo to function. My test setup has a quite firm nozzle, whilst allowing slight movement when the nozzle touches the bed.

Attach to a suitable amplifier circuit such as those available at http://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk

Probe away. :)

Join the discussion here http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,767998,787507,page=19#msg-787507

Youtube https://youtu.be/cPwi2WWcSV4

comments.text: Working on a CR-10 mount concept and was wondering if you think this would flex enough to trigger the piezo or not?
comments.author: jneilliii

comments.text: That looks good. Whilst I cannot say for certain that it will work it looks like it will. The force of the nozzle contacting will be concentrated into the area in which the piezo disc is situated. If it is not enough, you can always make the slit between the hotend mount and the carriage side deeper adding to this effect.
comments.author: jneilliii

comments.text: Thanks, That was part of the reasoning behind having the slit there in the first place, allowing for a little more twist to help trigger.  Going to print tonight and give it a test soon, just need to figure out where to mount the piezo board.

Parametric Wooden Box Ocarina.

This is a printable version of the Wooden Box Ocarina by TheOmegablood.

http://www.instructables.com/id/Make-an-ocarina-out-of-stock-sheet-wood/

For tuning instructions see the link above.

To build a single ocarina following parts are required:

  • Ocarina3_bottom.stl (1x)
  • Ocarina3_top.stl (1x)
  • 6 screws (M3 x 10)

Following parts are optional:

Ocarina3_tuningplate_1.stl
Ocarina3_tuningplate_2.stl

Remarks:

  • The instructions were missing the dimensions of one parameter: the height of the opening above the labium. I tried several heights and found an optimum around 7 mm. (it is the variable called "hOpening" in the scad file)

  • The base tuning (all holes closed) should be the E note. (or slightly lower). By adding tuning plates inside the box, the base note can be raised (by decreasing the volume). The same can also be achieved by drilling an extra tuning hole (but I would not recommend that).

  • I tested the part printed in ABS. But most likely any other material (e.g. PLA) will work just fine.

comments.text: Also one more question, how would you recomend me to print this. My printer has some issues with the mouth hole. Thank you
comments.author: dracolyteking

comments.text: Strange that your printer is having issues printing this object. You have to print the bottom part and top part separately of course (not as one single piece I mean).
comments.author: dracolyteking

comments.text: can you tell me what key each tuning plate will make the ocarina play in?
comments.author: dracolyteking

comments.text: Sorry, no, those tuning plates are meant only to get the tuning to the E note. If you want e.g. to set the base tone to the D note, a much thicker tuning plate will be required (you can of course also use multiple thinner plates). It might be possible to estimate (or calculate) the required volume of the plate (using the Helmholtz equation).
comments.author: dracolyteking

title: Mouse Wheel Replacement for Microsoft SideWinder X3 Laser Mouse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Perhaps i am the only one who is still using this old mouse. If not: print it and use it! Otherwise: get some inspiration for your own repairs! :)

The scroll wheel of the Microsoft SideWinder X3 mouse is well known for its self dissolvable capabilities.
After a few years the rubber of the wheel gets sticky, it is expanding, and finally you have to throw away your mouse, or dismantle the rubber coating of the wheel (which was what i did).

Because i like the mouse (and repairing broken stuff), and the design of a new coating is too easy, i went the long way, designing a full plastic scroll wheel assembly with all the features of the old wheel.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 pro x

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printed with a 0.3 mm nozzle and PLA.

Printed upside down (with the thin axle at the bottom), and with support, to slow down the printing process, allowing the axle to cool. Otherwise it would deform and handicap the scrolling function later.

I was not able to test if the detent works as expected, because the corresponding part in the mouse is broken too. (Next project?)

A slow printing speed is advisable.
Screenshot of the 3D model in Fusion 360.

title: TR10x2 lead screw nut 2040 aluminum carriage mng12h Hiwin

description.text:
Hi,
here is a metric lead screw nut for 2040 extrusion.
Its mounted via M4 bolts and M4 5.5mm brass insert is needed to be bolted to the extrusion. 5$ 100 pieces from aliexpress. As extrusión holes are 5.5mm ID.

Why 2040 Bosche aluminum extrusion and Hiwin MGN12?

The great thing is that the bolts on the hiwin carriage coincide with the 2040 channels, see picture. Which makes 50mm 2040 extrusion a great universal carriage plate.

Why TR10x2mm?
Because it's ideal for very long axis foam cutter. Up to 3m in length it's simpler to setup than 3 meter long belts and more precise and reliable, while providing the proper resolution. of course on 2600mm long axis, what i am building it will have maximum speed of say 500mm/min before whipping, but that's well enough for a foam cutter
of course simple cnc axis could be formed via that combo.

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
Crenelated edge wall tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. Can be stacked on Stone Corridor Tiles or Stone Wall Tiles with Pillars to create defensive walls.
These tiles are designed to line their wall up with walls from tiles butted up against their neighbors. These are designed to be used on the edge of the map or to give more usable space for the play area, particularly for 1x hallways which would be impossible to fit mins in unless the wall was moved. Because the wall now takes up some space, you will need to use edge buffers in some places to get the tiles to lay out properly.
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Painting

Painting was done in 5 layers.
  • Paint whole piece in black
  • Heavily dry brush with a dark grey
  • pick at least one other color (that could be stone) and paint some random stones, front and back.
  • dry brush with grey mixed with a little olive
  • lightly dry brush with a light grey, focusing most heavily on edges
    I paint the wall portion of the underside since it can be visible if the wall is stacked.

title: Lightweight Y carriage mount for Pi Camera

description.text:
I wanted to mount the camera on the Y carriage plate below the heated bed on a Wanhao Dupicator i3 (and others clones) but everything I tried or looked at seemed to be really bulky or very unstable leading to lots of blurry viewing, so I came up with this adaption of various bits found here on Thingiverse.

y carriage mounted Raspberry Pi (and others) camera mount and camera case to fit a Wanhao Duplicator i3 which I have running with Octoprint (http://octoprint.org/)

Based around the heated bed stabilisers from xyzaxis which work really well, along with an adaptation of dcgrigsby's pi arm mount and the arm mount pi camera case from berky93.

The camera support arm should be printed in ABS or PETG to withstand the heat from the heated bed. (The holes in the arm are to assist ABS printing rather than reduce weight)

To fit this make sure you loosen ALL the corner screws otherwise something might get bent while fitting. Chose either Left or Right files depending on where you want to mount the camera. (The bed stabalisers from xyzaxis on all for corners are recomended http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2036731

Whole thing weighs less than 11 grams. The focus on the Pi camera can be adjusted without having to open the case (Break the lens seal before assembly though)

Ideally use a nylon M3 bolt and nut to fix the camera case on the arm but titanium or steel will do!

Feedback very welcome.

Update 11/09/2017:Changed ends of arms to rest against y carriage rather than tuck under to avoid risk of hitting support frame.

See also https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2595116 one for 3-4mm aluminium carriage plate.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

No

0.15

Infill:

20

Notes:

author: aljohnsonwoofwoof

description.text:
So recently I took the plunge and bought a Maverick Scout rock crawler. But me being me, I decided to build a proper hard body scaler cab for the top of it.

I purchased a Tamiya Midnight Pumpkin black ABS shell and immediately cut the flat bed off to extend the cab.

Then I had to figure out what I could use to extend the body and an old fire cab came to mind.

Attached are the stl's for the cab. As usual there is the MK1 full thing and the MK2 wall and element files for easier printing.

comments.text: Awesome work! It'd be great if you worked on a drop-bed kit as well for the bed, I don't think anyone is doing that currently.
comments.author: kochiro

comments.text: Drop bed kit? What does that involve? New to scaler stuff so not sure what is required for the kit.
comments.author: kochiro

comments.text: The bed on the Midnight Pumpkin is only like 1cm deep but if it was true to scale it should be more like 3-4cm deep. A drop bed kit is something that you would use to make it deeper. So you would cut out the floor and inner walls of the Tamiya body, insert the new box and glue it into place. Here's an example pic of one where the floor is already cut out and the new drop bed is ready to be put in place. The term comes from "dropping the floor lower".
comments.author: ArdenFell

comments.text: Ah. So that’s what a drop bed kit is.
comments.author: kochiro

author: Bezbashennoe

description.text: This fan blade was designed in Autodesk Inventor 2017, all from scratch, creation stemmed from curiosity and boredom,it was rendered in Autodesk Showcase, Inventor Studio, & Solid Works, feel free to download these to your heart's content.

MiSTer - Case Universal v1.2 Updated

Update 2018-01-05
I added two new Top Shells now including buttons, the vents of the v5.2 case and an optional fan holding cage. The cage was matched for the noctua 40x40x20 mm fan but it should work well with other fans of similar dimensions. The noctua fan fits without glue or screwing requirements. Other fans might need to be glued in place.

The buttons are matched for the old 2.7 version of the I/O-Bord. Compared to the v5.2 these buttons are very much at the edge of the case. I did my best to accommodate the same buttons used in the universal case for the v5.2 I/O-Board. The buttons had to move quite a bit but ultimately feel even a little nicer and "clickier" compared to the other cases.

Everything should print in PLA in place without supports - layer height was again 0.18 mm.

I hope some guys still using the v2.7 I/O-Board will enjoy the new Top Shells. Your feedback is welcome as always.

The new parts are:
MiSTer Case Uni v2 Top Shell_Buttons.stl
MiSTer Case Uni v2 Top Shell_Buttons_Fan.stl

Update 2017-12-26
Added a new Top similar to the v5.2 of the case incl the new vents on the top shell.
You will have to provide your on fan bracket solution for now - until I come up with something. Object: MiSTer Case Uni v1 Top Shell_New_Vents.stl

Original Summary
I remixed the Universal Case for the MiSTer to now support the I/O-Board 2.7 .

Also I increased the distance between bottom and the pbc to allow for more air flow. Only the top shell of the case remains unchanged and can be used with this version 1.2.

The original screws of the DE10 Nano can now be used to fix the DE10 Nano inside the case (see pictures). If you find this to be too difficult try using sharp screws to prepare the holes. It works!

For the MiSTer logo sign please look at the remix section or at the original MiSTer 1.0 case.

Enjoy.

https://github.com/MiSTer-devel/Main_MiSTer/wiki

http://www.atari-forum.com/viewtopic.php?f=117&t=32067
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/s6JOXqiOqfw" ></iframe>

comments.text: Also... since this case is excellent, if you could add standoffs for the DE0-Nano as well, more centered in the case, the same case could be used for the DE0-Nano and DE10-Nano (two favorite FPGA boards).  Thank you.
comments.author: RogerTaylor1968

comments.text:
Thank you again for your suggestion. I sadly do not own a DE0-Nano, so that it makes limited sense for me to design a case of my own.
However, since you seem so interested in this case form factor let me reveal to you the open secret that I mainly used a customizer app for the basic shape of the box.
You can find this great design and app under this link
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1264391
comments.author: RogerTaylor1968

comments.text: This case is nice and is probably going to be required over the 1.0 and 1.1 due to the DE10-Nano's heat issue.  I would recommend larger openings above the fan and thicker slats.  They're mighty thin and sagging a little now.  Also, removing the cover to do maintenance becomes a pain with the fan connection wires which need to be long..  What if you slide the top vent towards the front panel and mount the fan on the back panel so the air flows through the case and out the back which would also allow the top to be removed without dealing with the fan.  Just some suggestions.  Keep up the great work.
comments.author: RogerTaylor1968

comments.text:
Thanks for the comment and your suggestions. The case was a "quick fix" to the arising heat issue encountered with the ao486 core. I also found the fan grill to be too thin. I will do a re-design and will accommodate for some changes that have to do with the 5.2 IO-Board (like 2nd SD-Card Slot). Re-design will take some time as I have to think about a different upper to lower shell connection. Also I am looking into integrating a larger fan like the A4x20 by noctua and I would like to get some action going for pushing down on the tactile switches of the IO-Board - maybe I will do different upper case shells to offer variety.
I will post the design her when it will be finished. :-)

description.text:
I made this support to have a fixed XT60 plug on the Peon230 quad. This could work for other quads as long as screws are 17mm apart.

It takes two M3 nuts, and gets screwed by the arms screws coming from bottom. You need 15mm long M3 screws but you should be able to use screws up to 17mm long...

The hole is a bit loose for nake XT60 connector, so I put a heat shrink on it and it's now friction-fit.

As you can see, I double-taped my FS X6B Rx on top of it, and secured it with a zip tie.

PS: I'm not native english speaker so if the description is not clear enough, please ask or suggest a better wording ;)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I used 0.25 layers and 90% fill. No support needed as I designed it for ease of print.

drill stand holder for drill's 1 to 10mm and
1 to 13mm

print_settings.Notes:: I printed using a 0.4mm Nozzle

title: Belted Extruder v4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Belted Extruder V.4

The Belted Extruder v4 is a Geared Extruder using a GT2 Belt and Aluminium Pulleys for optiomal accuracy, resolution and power.
The BEv4 is an updated version of my Belted Extruder V3. The v3 uses larger bearings.

I just published the Belted Extruder v4 2.85/3mm extruder seperately.

Proven record
I've been using the v3-4 for over a year and it's an extremely reliable design. My first one printed in PLA is still running!
Aside from countless users, I also know of several companies using these for their printer-farms by now, as they are very cheap to deploy and requires close to no maintenance.

What is a Belted Extruder and why is it build using Aluminium Pulleys?

  • It is a geared extruder
  • It uses 2 aluminium pulleys and a belt to drive the filament drivebit
  • Silent running due to belt usage
  • Higher accuracy and longelevity due to aluminium pulleys vs printed
  • Design of printed parts to achieve rigidity and stability
  • No hard to print gears which degrade and loose accuracy
  • All parts used are readily available, so not forcing you to buy key components from me
  • It measures 90mm by 52mm. All dimensions shown further down

Different models and features
There are different models/acessories uploaded. All centered around the standard model.

Defining changes to new models are listed seperately below the Belted Extruder V4 versions and BOM - standard features section further down on this page

Examples: ie: brackets for horizontal mounting and a version for GT2-200 belts + Version for 2.85mm/3mm filaments.

Printer:

My own xBot mix

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2, 0,1 or 0,05

Infill:

70-100%

Notes:
  • I printed using a 0.4mm Nozzle
  • I printed using 3 perimeters/borders - Do not print with 1 or 2 perimeters
  • The main Extruder part and Idler must have 50-70% infill depending on material used. - Use a strong infill. In Cura I use Tetrahedral - Do not skimp on infill. Infill matters for rigidity, which is important - Used 4 top/bottom layers. Meanig 0.8mm each
  • All the other parts is printed with 100% infill - important
  • The 2x8mmSpacer is printed 2 times, while all other parts are printed 1 time each

Get the scaling right

In order to save both time and filament I've added a file named "BEv4-DimensionsTesting.stl" which you should print as it is and check your Bearings fit in snugly.
Print it using the settings described in Print Settings above.

Scale it as needed and then use the same scaling for the main printer part as well.
It has build in Support, so no support needed.

I print mine at 100% and so should you, if you have an accurate printer.

Multi-extruder part
As a bonus I've added the file "BEv4-DimensionsTesting-Multi.3mf" where the support pieces are seperate, so they can be printed using a seperate extruder.
This is a test and I have not had time to test it myself yet

Render of the BEv4-DimensionsTesting used to get the scaling right.

Standard features - BOM
  • 1x 60-GT2 aluminium pulley
  • 1x 16-GT2 Pulley for the small gear, which gives a ratio of 1:3.75 - you can use a 20-GT2 pulley for 1:3 ratio
  • Strongly advice you to buy the Hobb-Goblin - 8mm Hobbed Shaft Kit from E3D - you can also buy it from Filastruder if that is easier for you.
    All necessary nuts and spacers for the filamentdrive assembly are included when buying these
  • 2x Push-fittings with 6mm thread for 1,75mm filament - Make sure the filament can pass all the way through it!
  • 172-GT2 Belt needed - 172mm/86 teeth
  • A Nema 17 motor
  • 3x 688 bearings. 8x16x5 - Type doesn't matter.
  • 1x m3 25mm Rounded Head screw - for Idler
  • 1x m3 15mm Rounded Head screw - for Idler bearing
  • 1x m3 40mm Partially Threaded Socket Head screw - for Tightener
  • 1x 10mm steel spring - for Tightener
  • 6x m3 nuts
  • 4x m3 Rounded Head screw - for motor
  • 4x m3 spacers - for motor
  • Build in mount points on 2 sides. Compatible with standard Nema 17 brackets - 31mm mount hole distance from center to center.
  • A drop of Wood Glue, or similar. Not Superglue, and most assuredly not threadlocker as it eats away plastic
Standard - Model without build in support

The file BEv4-std-NoSupport is the same as the standard, but without build in supports.

Mounting Brackets for Standard version

These brackets only varies in StdBracket_3mm.stl use m3 screws, and StdBracket-5mm.stl using 5mm nuts.

Intended for horizontal mounting on 2020 or similar Extrusions.

Render of StdBracket_3mm.stk mounting bracket. BEv4 With EndMount

Same as standard but with the addition of mountpoints at the end.
It is 5mm longer than the standard version.
Mount points are spaced as normal Nema 17 for easy mounting.
Excellent for mounting on the backside of Ultimakers for instance.

BEv4-With_EndMount 200-GT2 Belt version

I do recommend using the smaller std version with 172-GT2 belt, but if you for some reason would rather use 188-200 GT2 Belts, you can use this version.
File for this version is: BEv4-GT2-200.stl

  • Added the lower-end mounting holes to this one in order to stiffen it up some
  • Added internal bewelfeatures to strengthen it
  • 3 Perimeters and 70% infill applies even more to this version, as it is longer, so more strain on the center piece
  • 15mm longer than std version
Picking the right motor
  • I use a small quality 0.9 steps pancake motor SKU: 17HM08-1204S

Usage
  • You do not have to open Idler to load filament, which makes it very easy to change filament
  • If the filament drivebit doesn't grab onto inserted filament automatically, you need to loosen the TightenerNutholder
  • Belt is tightened by sliding motor downwards - Do not use excessive force or you can damage Nema motor
Capabilities
  • I have succesfully printed using Shore D40 and D60 Flexibles, where number denotes softness. Pure Ninjaflex (shore A 85) does not work due to bowden.
    * Read wiki: Shore durometer if interested.

Step 1 - Remove Support
  • Use a fitting plier to remove the 2 pieces of support from BEv4-std
Step 2 - Cleaning the pieces
  • Remove burrs, blobs, strings etc. you might have from all your printed pieces
  • Make sure your filament can pass through the the extruder without hitting something.
Step 3 - Add m3 nuts to main part
  • Add 2 m3 nuts in the BEv4-std part idler-hinge.
  • Add 2 m3 nuts for mounting the extruder to your printer.
  • You might use a plier to press the m3 nuts into place.
Step 4 - Hobbed-bolt and Pulley assembly
  • Insert 2x 688 bearings into the main extruder part: BEv4-std.stl.
  • Insert the E3D Hobbed Bolt through the bearings and center it.
  • Insert one of the printed 2x8mmSpacer onto either end of the hobbed bolt
  • Insert one of the ø8 steel spacers onto either end of the hobbed bolt.
    Came with the E3D Hobbed Bolt
  • Insert the 60-GT2 big Aluminium Pulley onto the Hobbed bolt, on the flat side of the extruder
    Long end of Hobbed bolt should be on this side
  • It is IMPORTANT to put the grub screws outwards or you will bend the extruder once you start using it. YES the grub screws are meant to be set into the threads
  • Make sure the Hobbed Bolt it centered, by looking at the drive-bit and the filamentgroove in the middle of the Extruder...
    ... then tighten the 2 grub-screws on the 60-GT2 pulley
  • Inser the Teeth Lock spacer and the normal m8 Nut onto the side of the pulley
    These came with the E3D Hobbed Bolt
  • Use a pipe-wrench or similiar tool to grib onto the 60-GT2 Pulley. On the round part where grub-screws are insert - not on the Teeth.
    - While you hold onto the big Pulley, you tighten down the m8 screw.
    - Don't overdo it. Just enough to make it stay in place.
  • Now insert the m8 Lock Nut onto the other end of the Hobbed bolt and tigten it. - Use the pipe-wrench trick from earlier. - Do not overtighten it. Just make it snug.
  • Make sure the assembly turns nicely. If it's very tight you need to loosen it. Some resistance is fine, but it must run smoothly and should run without use of force
  • If you can push/pull the assembly back and forth in the printed part, you tighten it a bit more.
Step 5 - Push-Fittings
  • Use an M6 screw and screw it into the holes/threads for the Push-fittings
    This makes it much easier to install the Push-Fittings.
  • Use a plier to get a firm grib on one of the Push-Fitting and screw it into the threaded holes.
    I recommend finding a tool where you can push the Push-Fitting into the hole while turning
Optional Step 6 - Idler
  • Use a plier to pressfit a m3 nut into the idler
  • Use the pipe-wrench or similar to press the printed IdlerBearing.stl into the last 608 bearing
  • Put the printed Idlerbearing_spacer on the opposite site of the bearing and insert the parts into the printed Idler.stl
  • Use a m3 16mm screw to fix the Idler bearing in place
    The bearing would try to turn when inserting the screw. This is normal, so just push on the screw while holding onto the bearing and idler
  • Attach the assembled Idler onto the Extruderpart BEv4-std.stl idler hinge and use the M3 25mm screw to fix it
    - The screw must go in from the top side and come out on the flat side of the Extruder: meaning it come out and is attached to the outer M3 nut
Step 7 - Idler adjust mechanism
  • Insert the M3 40mm screw through the top of the printed Idler
  • Insert the printed ReleaseTab onto the screw with the rounded edges facing towards the Idler
  • Insert the 10mm spring
  • Insert a M3 nut into the Tightener-Nutholder, which you then screw onto the m3 40mm screw
    The screw goes through the pritned part of the Tightener-Nutholder before entering the m3 nut
  • Tighten it untill you can see about 1cm of the threadding at the end of the screw
  • Do NOT put on a drop of ThreadLocker! I did this and it east away the plastic. You can use some nail polish or just a drop of WoodGlueonto the thread below the m3 nut.
  • Turn down the Tightener-Nutholder untill it is about 5mm from the end of the screw
You might add a drop of Thread-locker or woodglue to the Finger-Tighethener if you find it too fiddly, like in the video.

Major changes
  • The goal of V4 was to make it more compact, and redesign the Idler release system
  • Using smaller 688 bearings (8*16*5) instead of the old 608 bearings (8*22*7).
    Innerd diameter/center hole * Outer diameter * How thick it is.
  • Redesigned the Idler latch/release system to be an integral part of the design and not protrude upwards
  • Compressed the space between the 2 Push-fittings, making the push-fitting less protruding.
  • Compacted staggered design resulted in a more rigid part when printed
  • More rigid opbject allowed for removal of the lower end mount parts, which led to a smaller end product
  • Tweaked the filament channel
  • It now requires less force to extrude filament due to the tweaks
  • Scaled the Push-fitting threads to make it much easier to insert the Push-Fittings
  • Due to tweaks, blobs at the end of filaments should now pass more easily through the extruder (in reverse) without loosening the Idler
  • Less materials used
  • Redesigned all objects making for an overall much easier print
  • It is running in reverse compared to my v3
Note: The downloadable file has been scaled up by 1%

17th January 2018

Created seperate "thing" for the 2.85mm / 3mm extruder as people couldn't find it.
Removed it from this "thing"

5th january 2018

Uploaded modified model of the Belted Extruder V4 2.85/3mm
This fixes an issues where the Bowden tube was pushed out of the extruer.

16th December 2017

Uploaded modelfiles for 2.85/3mm model.
This model consist of basefile + idler
BEv4_2.85-3mm.stl
3mm_Idler v1.stl

2nd November 2017

Added the following to the assembly instructions as I learned this was why some decided to assemble the extruder with pulleys facing opposite way as my design:

Important notice on mounting the Hobb-goblin hobbed bolt
It is important to put the grub screws outwards, as shown in my photos, or you will bend the extruder once you start using it. This might lead to uneven extrusion.
YES the grub screws are meant to be set into the threads

9. Oct 2017

Added new model BEv4-With_EndMount with mountpoints at the end.

9. Oct. 2017

Encountered issues with the STL files on linux systems using S3D so new versions of the following files has been uploaded to fix this issue.

  • BEv4-std
  • BEv4-std-NoSupport

Thanks to hcumberdale for bringing the issue to light

19. Sept 2017:
  • Added version without support
  • Minor tweak to Support for the center bearing area
  • Minor tweak to how the filament is transfered out into the exit Bowden

Hello mjf55.
Thanks :) Contrary to what MKSA seems to belive, this is not some experiment. I've been using the v3 for a year or so and never looked back. This v4 was made in order to make it an even smaller package and optimized the printing process while at it.
comments.author: mjf55

comments.text: As a side note, the one thing I have noticed is that I can't get as much pressure on the filament with the idler as I could with your v3 extruder. I am getting adequate pressure to print PLA and PETG but it seems that if I try to tighten the tension screw further, the nut-holder wants to pop out of it's position. I've yet to try a stiffer spring which I imagine would fix this (I need to source one) but I'm wondering if you ran into this same issue?
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: Why would you put more pressure on the filament? I recommend not tightening it more than absolutely necessary as you just risk deforming your filament and in worst case mess up extrusionrate.
comments.author: donnyb99

comments.text: It was fine for normal printing but not for high jerk pressure advance. The Titan spring made all the difference in the world.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: So this MKSA guy is a complete knob. I figured I'd chime in here as I have authentic Titan extruders, Greg/Wade's, a worm screw based one and both your belted V3 and V4. I use high retract speeds and high retract jerk along with pressure advance on my main printer and the main reason I wanted to move away from the Titan is that it was simply too damn noisy with all the quick retracts and advances that come from the pressure advance algorithm. Your belted designs eliminated 90% of that noise. I've got my v4 up and running now (with a custom bracket I drew up for my purposes) and I'm enjoying it immensely. I, for one, am very happy for your designs and have used them to directly replace my Titan on my most used printer.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: Thank you for sharing your observations :)  It's nice having my own oberservations validated by someone else + nice when my goal for the Extruders succeeded regarding the noise.
comments.author: donnyb99
